english: have nothing better to do (lit. stuffed from eating)

etymology.description: 吃 + 饱 + 了 + 撑 + 的 = so full that one is ‘propped/stuffed,’ hence doing pointless things out of idleness.
etymology.interpretation: Colloquial, mildly scolding way to say someone is doing something unnecessary because they’re bored and overfull—“have nothing better to do.” Often used to chide nitpicking or meddling.
etymology.simplification: 飽→饱: 食 radical simplified to 饣 while keeping phonetic 包; 撐→撑: right component 爭 simplified to 争 with the hand radical 扌 unchanged. 吃、了、的 are the same in both scripts.

parts.english: to eat; to consume; to suffer/endure; be stumped by
full (from eating); satiated; replete; to satisfy
aspect particle (completed); change of state; modal particle; end-of-action marker
to prop/support; to hold up; to be overstuffed; to sustain
structural particle; possessive ’s; nominalizer; modifier marker

examples.chinese: 你是不是吃饱了撑的，整天发牢骚(你是不是吃飽了撐的，整天發牢騷)。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ shì bù shì chī bǎo le chēng de, zhěngtiān fā láosāo.
examples.english: Are you just bored and overfull, complaining all day for no reason.

examples.chinese: 他没事乱管别人的事，真是吃饱了撑的(他沒事亂管別人的事，真是吃飽了撐的)。
examples.pinyin: Tā méi shì luàn guǎn biérén de shì, zhēn shì chī bǎo le chēng de.
examples.english: He meddles in others’ business for no reason—really has nothing better to do.

examples.chinese: 吃饱了撑的，才会去半夜搬石头玩(吃飽了撐的，才會去半夜搬石頭玩)。
examples.pinyin: Chī bǎo le chēng de, cái huì qù bànyè bān shítou wán.
examples.english: Only someone with nothing better to do would move rocks for fun at midnight.
